title: Quiz 1: Multiple Pregnancies
topicName: Unit Three Part Two : Abnormal Labour and Puerperium
description: Assessment on types of twins, diagnosis, complications, and management of multiple pregnancies.

questions.question: Match the twin type with its correct characteristics:

pairs.right: One ovum, one spermatozoon, always same sex
Two ova, two spermatozoa, can be different sexes

questions.explanation: Uniovular twins develop from a single fertilized ovum and are identical. Binovular twins come from two separate ova. The incidence of multiple pregnancies varies, with twins being the most common.
questions.hint: Think about the origin of the egg and sperm for each type.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical signs suggestive of a multiple pregnancy during palpation? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Fundal height is smaller than dates
Two foetal poles are revealed at the fundus
The head feels smaller than expected for the uterus size
One large foetal back is felt clearly

questions.explanation: In multiple pregnancies, the uterus is larger than dates, two poles may be felt, the head feels small relative to the uterus, and multiple small parts (limbs) are palpable.
questions.hint: Consider findings that indicate more than one fetus is occupying the space.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for the management of the second twin during delivery:

items.text: Deliver the first twin and clamp the cord
Check the lie and presenting part of the second twin
Correct the lie if necessary (e.g., external version)
Rupture membranes if head is engaged
Administer oxytocin after anterior shoulder delivery

questions.explanation: After the first twin, immediate assessment of the second twin's lie is crucial. Membranes should only be ruptured once the presentation is longitudinal and engaged to prevent cord prolapse.

questions.question: If the second twin lies in a transverse position and external version fails, the doctor will perform an ___BLANK___ version to deliver the baby as a ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Internal podalic version involves reaching into the uterus to grasp the feet and turning the baby to a breech presentation for delivery.
questions.hint: This maneuver is done inside the uterus to grasp the feet.

questions.question: What is a 'Locked Twin' complication?

options.text: When both twins engage in the pelvis simultaneously preventing descent
When the cords of both twins become entangled
When the placentas fuse together preventing separation
When the cervix closes between the birth of the first and second twin

questions.explanation: Locked twins is a rare emergency where the chin of the first twin (breech) locks with the chin of the second twin (cephalic), preventing delivery.
questions.hint: Think about physical obstruction between the two fetuses.

questions.question: Preeclampsia is three times more common in multiple pregnancies than in single pregnancies.
questions.explanation: The increased placental mass and hormonal changes in multiple pregnancies significantly increase the risk of hypertensive disorders like preeclampsia.
questions.hint: Consider the physiological strain of twins on the mother.

questions.question: What specific complication should be anticipated if the second twin is smaller and the membranes rupture while the head is still high?
questions.explanation: Cord prolapse is a significant risk with the second twin, especially if the presenting part is not well applied to the cervix when membranes rupture.
questions.hint: A life-threatening emergency involving the lifeline of the fetus.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a routine antenatal management strategy for multiple pregnancy?

options.text: Routine induction of labour at 36 weeks

questions.explanation: Routine induction at 36 weeks is not standard; management involves monitoring to prevent prematurity and allowing pregnancy to continue if healthy, though post-maturity is avoided.
questions.hint: Consider what would be an intervention versus monitoring.

questions.question: Identify the maternal complications associated with multiple pregnancy. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Multiple pregnancy increases the risk of polyhydramnios, pressure symptoms, severe minor disorders, and PPH due to overdistension of the uterus.
questions.hint: Think about the effects of a larger uterus and higher hormone levels.

questions.question: On auscultation, a diagnosis of twins can be suspected if two foetal heartbeats are heard with a difference of at least:

options.text: They must be exactly the same

questions.explanation: A difference of 10-20 beats per minute between two distinct heart sounds, heard by two observers simultaneously, suggests twins.
questions.hint: The difference must be significant enough to distinguish from one heart rate varying.
